results.content: So far very clear and I am able to visualize what is going on behind the scenes of the django framework. It's very important to be able to understand how things affect other things to really understand what you are learning. For instance views.hello in the urlpatterns list is refering to the views.py file we created and hello is the method inside of that file. So now that I understand how all this is linked together it doesn't seem so difficult any more. Most of these courses I've done (And I have done A LOT!) just tell you what to click on and type, but they don't really explain very well WHY you are doing what you are doing. I hope the rest of this course is exactly like it has been so far.

results.content:
I really liked Nick's energy and enthusiasm, and thought the exercises, explanations, and challenge problems worked quite well. Things progressed nicely and I felt engaged throughout. 

The frequent misspelling was a bit distracting, and both the inline javascript and the styling via html tables was a bit amateurish. Admittedly those weren't the purpose of the course, but it would be valuable to at least note those things. 

Overall I'm quite pleased. Thanks Nick.

It's a good introduction, but very basic, also a lot of time is spent teaching Bootstrap/Server stuff. Also some time is spent doing stuff that was already done like 3x before, this should be skipped, so we'd have time for more useful information. It's a good course for people who never did anything for web, it's an ok course for people who already does web dev.

results.content:
I'm a professional self-taught programmer and this course did an amazing job at teaching the basics of Django.  The course was a little slow at times, but having taken countless MOOCs, I'd rather the instructor move at a slower than normal pace rather than skip too much since you can fast forward around if you already feel confident about what you learned.

Nick has an excellent teaching style and will explain nearly everything he does and will show you even the most commonly encountered errors in the process of building the websites he shows you how to build.  Although this course, being for Django 1.11, is a little outdated, I've also watched several of Nick's courses both on Udemy and on other platforms and I've always had my expectations blown!

results.content: I really appreciate his style of teaching.  He is to the point and doesn't try to fill in all of the gaps that people might have with surrounding tech.  I came here to understand Django and I feel that is what I got.  The only addition that I'd recommend is that there would be a lesson or two on Django architecture, its limitations, how to scale it, etc.  So at this point, I understand Django, but I really don't know why I'd select it other than I'd like to use Python for server side web apps.

results.content:
Pros:
You get a quick view of the Django and start to create apps really fast.

Cons:
Unfortunately It does not correspond to the Ultimate Guide as the course states. Despite building three apps, they are silly and do not seem real-world apps. Plus, the instructor does not follow the best practices like tests, automatic deploy, AWS S3 and versioning with GIT. It lacks diving into forms and other topics that are really important. It does not help you to build a real-world app with Django.

The instructor has terrific energy and enthusiasm and I enjoy his style.  He has good subject matter knowledge and is following a progression in terms of what he's teaching in a logical way that builds on prior content effectively.

There are a couple of issues that make me shave a star or two off my rating.  First, at this point in the course (I'm at the end of the blog section) I feel like he isn't explaining enough about some of the things he's teaching.  For instance, there are some pseudo-Python commands he's using in the HTML to do things like handle static images or loop through post entries that he isn't explaining in terms of how they work, what other commands you can use in those situations, etc.  I gather they're used inside Django's render engine to do special processing, but a deeper explanation of this would be extremely helpful.

I also find that he is a little too unplanned in his presentation.  Mistakes are common, some of which he notices and fixes, others that he doesn't.  I feel like these recordings could have used another couple of dry runs to really nail the flow before recording, just to give it some more polish.  But this is a minor point really.

Above all, the most important thing about a course is how effective it is at teaching the material.  So far, it's been very effective for me.

results.content:
I’m halfway through the course now and it has been great so far (so I’ll update this when finished). Nick has a clear but concise way of explaining things.  The projects have real life applications which makes this course very engaging. There are some small things that have been outdated since there have been slight modifications with newer versions of Django. Looking at the Q&A section can help tremendously with that and he is pretty quick to respond to questions if you sent him a personal message.

The only real critique for me would be the fact that many of the variables, pages, classes, and functions are named extremely similar during the blog project.  As a beginner, who goes back to review the code, this may become confusing. Personally I would've liked to see more distinguishable object names so that I have a better idea where each one comes from.

I consider myself a beginner with some previous experience in Django and HTML. If you are in that boat, this course will be great for you. If Nick comes out with another Django course, I will most certainly take that as well!

results.content:
I'm an experienced python user and this was a decent introduction to web development in Django.  I would recommend to people that are beginners if the price was right.

Pros:
- Course is short
- Curriculum covers several major themes for a database driven web application

Cons:
- Did not receive too much guidance on best practices for real applications
- very high level and little to zero explanation of the "why" behind certain actions

results.content: I suggest coming to this class already knowing at least some HTML, CSS and Python.  Since I did, I find the class a great introduction to Django.  I am two thirds of the way done and have already gotten more than my money's worth.  Nick is really enthusiastic and engaging, which makes the lectures fun to watch.  In just a few days I feel like I have a good overview of how Django works.  I am taking this class simultaneously with another class that goes into a lot of detail about HTML and CSS, so they make a perfect pair.  I took this class up until the point of needing to know the HTML, switched over to the other class and studied HTML, then came back here and finished with Nick.  It seems to flow perfectly that way.  Be prepared to go offline and study bootstrap, since he is using an older version, some of the stuff won't work and you have to look up the new way of doing it.  But if that seems aggravating to you, then development is not for you as that is the norm!

Be prepared to go offline and study bootstrap, since he is using an older version, some of the stuff won't work and you have to look up the new way of doing it. But if that seems aggravating to you, then development is not for you as that is the norm!

results.content:
I think so far it's great - the only comment I would make (reason why I give 4.5 instead of 5 stars) is that perhaps rather than  selling the advantages of each thing we do, it would be great to know why some things are done in a particular way (structurally, architecturally). For example what's the connection between views, models and urls, why do you put certain pieces of code in one file and not the other file... those feel a bit "recipe-style" for me. 

Having said that, Nick's got a lot of good energy and I've been mimicking everything he does on my other screen so I certainly feel like I'm getting more dexterous. The website examples he chose to do in the course are the right level and feel real-world enough so the level of interest is high. Great course.

response.content: Hey Fernando. I really appreciate the great feedback! I'm always looking for ways to improve as an instructor, and this is very helpful. I'm glad you're having fun though. It's great to have you in the course! Feel free to message me if you have any specific questions :)

results.content: Excellent introductory course on Django. Nick does not waste your time by trying to turn you into a Django Jedi with 40+ hours of bloated content, much of which will be outdated or obsolete in a year anyway. Instead you will walk away with a rock solid foundation on Django's basic constructs and the confidence to quickly build and deploy sophisticated web applications.

results.content:
A great course for not only beginners but for people who'd like to do a quick Django refresher. Even I'm working with Django for a while already, I learned one or two new hints that will help me to improve my code in the future.
Nick is very positive, engaging and cheerful teacher and he did a good job screencasting all these exercises for us. Just do less "bada booms!" next time ;)

The issues with the course I've encountered:
- basic methods of work with static files on the Django project such as .css and this is why some css rule have been hard-coded in the last project. NEVER EVER DO IT, PLEASE :)
- Disqus didn't work for me. I posted my question but never got the answer.

Overall, a nice course.

results.content:
This is the perfect Django course for beginners. Personally I've never touched Python or Django and this course made me good enough to get started at building practical webapps based on Django. The Python refresher section at the beginning is pretty nifty, and I like how there are challenges etc. throughout to help students solidify understanding!

This course has a great balance of difficulty and content (i.e. concepts are not too difficult to grasp, yet you can build quite a lot of things just with what's taught alone). There are many other concepts taught which is great for breadth knowledge.

A little thing I wanted to comment on is that the application of Bootstrap can be improved (e.g. using Bootstrap row and cols instead of table, using Bootstrap forms instead of just buttons, etc.) but you can easily look those stuff up if you are interested.

Overall a great course to get started and I highly recommend taking this course! As a bonus, Nick is, in my opinion, probably one of the most entertaining instructors I've seen Udemy so far.
